\begin{abstract}
	We show that the existence of $\{\pm 1\}$-matrices having largest possible determinant is equivalent to the existence of certain tournament matrices.
	In particular, we prove a recent conjecture of Armario.
	We also show that large submatrices of conference matrices are determined by their spectrum.
\end{abstract}

A $\{\pm 1\}$-matrix of order $n$ is called an \textbf{EW matrix} if it satisfies \eqref{eq:ew}.
Clearly Hadamard matrices and EW matrices are D-optimal designs.
Note that it is known that EW matrices exist only if $2(n-1)$ is the sum of two squares, hence there is no analogue of the Hadamard conjecture for EW matrices.

A \textbf{tournament matrix} is a $\{0,1\}$-matrix $A$ such that $A + A^\top = J-I$. 
A tournament matrix is called \textbf{doubly regular} if, for some $t \in \mathbb N$, we have $AA^\top = tJ + (t+1)I$.
